title: Amending Executive Order 12425 Designating Interpol as a Public International Organization Entitled To Enjoy Certain Privileges, Exemptions, and Immunities

enrichment.summary: This executive order updates a previous order to grant INTERPOL, the International Criminal Police Organization, certain legal privileges and immunities as a recognized international organization in the United States. Essentially, it modifies the existing designation to extend these benefits more fully under U.S. law.
potential_concerns: Enhanced privileges and immunities granted to INTERPOL may complicate oversight and accountability of law enforcement activities by federal officers within U.S. jurisdiction.
The expanded diplomatic immunities could create tensions with foreign governments and officials if perceived as preferential treatment or interference in sovereignty.
Granting broader immunities to INTERPOL might risk undermining domestic legal processes, potentially impacting crime victims and accused persons indirectly through international policing actions.
Increased cooperation under the amended order may raise concerns about data sharing and privacy protections for U.S. citizens handled by an international body.
